Award.AbstractNarration:
In the last thirty years, much of the progress in our understanding of 3-dimensional topology has been grounded in hyperbolic (non- euclidean) geometry and in topological quantum field theory. However, these two branches of mathematics have long evolved in parallel, without much interaction with each other. Hypothetical bridges between these two fields are now beginning to emerge. One of them is the Volume Conjecture, experimentally verified by a few computations, which connects the asymptotic growth of the Jones polynomials of a knot to the volume of the canonical hyperbolic metric of its complement. The goal of the Project is to develop a conceptual framework combining the two points of view. The Project has a 2- dimensional component, focussed on the representation theory of the quantum Teichmuller space of a surface, as introduced by physicists to model quantum gravity in dimension 2+1. A second part of the Project builds on the insight gained in dimension 2 to develop invariants of hyperbolic 3-dimensional manifolds, closely related to the objects appearing in the Volume Conjecture.

The Project aims at gaining a better understanding of 3-dimensional geometry, such as the problem of deciding when two knotted curves in space can be deformed to each other. One traditional approach to this problem involves the algebraic manipulation of certain polynomials associated to pictorial descriptions of these curves. Another powerful technique, with widely used software implementation, uses hyperbolic non-euclidean geometry. Experimental evidence suggests an unexpected connection between these two points of view. The goal of the Project is to develop technical and conceptual tools to confirm (or disprove) this connection, and to better understand the phenomena involved.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In its intellectual merit, the Project aimed at gaining a better understanding of 3-dimensional geometry, such as the problem of deciding when two knotted curves in space can be deformed to each other. One traditional approach to this problem involves the algebraic manipulation of certain polynomials associated to pictorial descriptions of these curves. Another powerful technique, with widely used software implementation, uses hyperbolic non-euclidean geometry. Experimental evidence suggests an unexpected connection between these two points of view. The goal of the Project was to develop technical and conceptual tools to confirm (or disprove) this connection, and to better understand the phenomena involved.

The PI, his students and collaborators obtained many results in this direction, which have appeared (or will appear) in major mathematics journals. The main outcomes of this program have been the development and analysis of specific methods to move from the algebraic manipulations of knots to hyperbolic geometry. One discovery stands out, because it involves several mysterious "miraculous cancelations": in an algebraic computation whose output is expected to be extremely large and complex, most of the terms unexpectedly cancel out and the outcome of the computation is surprisingly small. In mathematics, such phenomena often point to deep mathematical facts that are at the origin of these cancelations. In this specific case, they provide further evidence that the properties that were experimentally discovered will eventually find a rigorous explanation.

 

In its broader impacts, the Project contributed to the education of 5 graduate students. These students have now received their PhDs, and are holding positions at various academic institutions.

The Project also provided material for the PI to give several talks to middle school students, undergraduate students and college math clubs on various aspects of geometry. The general goal of these talks was to show how mathematics (and in particular geometry) can be really exciting and to entice students to pursue further studies in mathematics. With the same goals in mind, the PI published an undergraduate textbook that is directly inspired by the mathematics underlying the Project and, after beginning at a very elementary level, progressively introduces the student to more and more advanced matherial; this textbook is now used for advanced undergraduate classes at many universities worldwide.

The mathematics underlying the main project has led to an interesting interaction between mathematics and engineering. With the relatively recent emergence of very massive networks, such as those arising from the Internet or data mining, it has become clear that new ideas are needed to attack the corresponding challenges.  Some of the techniques and concepts of hyperbolic non-euclidean geometry, that are central to the Project, have found unexpected applications to the analysis of traffic on very large networks, such as the backbone of the Internet. The new conceptual insights arising from this work, developed by the PI and two of his engineering collaborators, fit remarkably well some of the experimental data.
